payload.name: imprecise-probability
payload.core: Represent uncertainty with probability intervals [P_lower, P_upper] when evidence is insufficient to justify a point estimate. Separates 'unknown' (wide interval) from 'unlikely' (narrow interval near zero). Use when forced priors would be arbitrary or when robustness across probability assignments matters.

out.d: [P_L, P_U] bounds on event probability with justification for each bound
set of probability distributions compatible with evidence constraints
how conclusions change across the interval range
claims that hold for all distributions in credal set
action choice under specified ambiguity rule (maximin, Gamma-maximin, etc.)
information that would tighten bounds, with expected reduction

proc: identify whether interval justified: use when (a) no defensible point prior, (b) experts disagree >20% range, or (c) stakes require robustness audit
elicit bounds separately: P_lower from minimal evidence threshold, P_upper from maximal compatible evidence
construct credal set: all distributions satisfying constraints; often convex hull of extremes
propagate intervals: lower bound of conjunction = product of lowers; upper of disjunction = min(1, sum of uppers)
identify robust conclusions: claims where sign/direction unchanged across full interval
classify non-robust cases: (a) decision-sensitive (interval spans threshold), (b) direction-uncertain, (c) order-uncertain (ranking changes)
select decision rule: maximin (pessimistic), maximax (optimistic), Gamma-maximin (weighted), E-admissibility (non-dominated set)
report ambiguity cost: expected-value difference between point estimate and robust action
plan interval reduction: identify observations that maximally reduce [P_L, P_U] width
check: interval bounds each have explicit evidential justification, not symmetric padding
P_lower derived from minimal supporting evidence, P_upper from absence of refuting evidence
unknown (wide interval) distinguished from unlikely (narrow near zero) in outputs
propagation rules documented (independence assumed? conjunction/disjunction method?)
decision rule stated before examining which action wins
sensitivity table shows conclusions at interval endpoints and midpoint
robust conclusions labeled; non-robust flagged with sensitivity range
ambiguity cost quantified if decision differs from point-estimate optimum

diff.bayesian-probabilistic: IP uses intervals when no defensible point prior; Bayesian requires single prior (even if sensitivity-tested). IP says 'I don't know P'; Bayesian says 'P=0.5 pending evidence'.
diff.robust-worst-case: Robust optimizes only at worst endpoint; IP considers full interval, may use Gamma-maximin or E-admissibility. IP is uncertainty representation; robust is decision rule.
diff.evidential-dempster-shafer: DS allocates mass to sets, derives [Bel,Pl] structurally; IP directly elicits probability bounds. DS combines via Dempster rule; IP propagates via interval arithmetic.
diff.qualitative-probability: Qualitative orders events (A > B > C) without numeric bounds; IP provides numeric intervals. Use qualitative when even bounds feel arbitrary.
diff.fuzzy-logic: Fuzzy handles vagueness (boundary of 'tall'); IP handles uncertainty (probability of rain). Fuzzy grades membership; IP bounds probability.

fail.desc: Intervals too wide to discriminate options; analysis stalls awaiting unattainable precision.
signals: interval spans decision-relevant threshold (e.g., [0.3, 0.7] when threshold is 0.5)
all candidate actions have overlapping expected-utility intervals
repeated requests for more data without specifying what would suffice
no decision rule adopted despite overlapping intervals
ambiguity cost not quantified, so value of narrowing unknown

mit.m: adopt explicit decision rule before analysis
mit.test: rule named (maximin/Gamma/E-admissible) and applied to select action
VoI estimate exists showing expected interval reduction and decision value

mit.m: set ambiguity budget: maximum acceptable [P_U - P_L]
mit.test: threshold stated (e.g., 0.2) and intervals exceeding it flagged

mit.m: use robust satisficing: accept first option meeting threshold across full interval
mit.test: satisficing threshold defined and at least one option evaluated against it

mit.m: decompose: narrow sub-intervals where evidence stronger, accept wide elsewhere
mit.test: interval decomposition table shows narrowed components

mit.m: time-box analysis: decide by deadline with current intervals
mit.test: deadline set and decision made despite residual ambiguity

use: expert disagreement: elicit bounds from each expert, take convex hull
regulatory risk assessment: auditors require robustness, not optimistic point estimates
novel domains: no historical base rates, prior would be fabricated
high-stakes irreversibility: cost of wrong point estimate exceeds cost of wider interval
model uncertainty: ensemble of models yields probability range, not single forecast
adversarial settings: opponent may exploit known point estimate

rel.r: alternative: use Bayesian when defensible point prior exists
decision rule often paired with IP uncertainty
alternative interval framework via mass functions
consumes IP intervals via ambiguity-aware rules
fallback when even bounds are unjustified
decision rule minimizing worst relative loss under IP

ex.sit: Estimating P(novel pathogen becomes pandemic) for resource allocation. No historical base rate; three experts give 5%, 25%, 40%.
steps: reject point estimate: expert spread (5%-40%) exceeds 20% threshold for Bayesian prior
elicit bounds: P_lower=0.05 (minimum expert), P_upper=0.40 (maximum expert)
propagate to decision: expected lives saved = [50K, 400K] × P = [2.5K, 160K]
robust conclusion: intervention justified if cost < 2.5K life-equivalents (holds at lower bound)
non-robust: optimal scale varies 5× across interval—requires decision rule
apply Gamma-maximin (gamma=0.5): weight 50% to worst case, 50% to midpoint → scale decision
VoI: serology study could narrow to [0.15, 0.30], worth $X if decision changes

robust_conclusions: intervention threshold met at lower bound
asset.ambiguity_cost: expected value loss vs point-estimate optimum: $Y

vs_bayesian.symptom: using IP when a defensible base rate exists
vs_bayesian.diagnostic: can you cite a reference class with >100 instances? if yes, use Bayesian with that prior
vs_bayesian.resolution: IP for deep uncertainty; Bayesian for actuarial uncertainty with data

vs_wide_confidence_interval.symptom: treating frequentist CI as probability interval
vs_wide_confidence_interval.diagnostic: CI is repeated-sampling property; IP is epistemic state about single event
vs_wide_confidence_interval.resolution: CI bounds parameter under sampling; IP bounds probability directly

vs_sensitivity_analysis.diagnostic: sensitivity varies inputs to see output change; IP represents genuine uncertainty in inputs
vs_sensitivity_analysis.resolution: sensitivity is method; IP is uncertainty representation that motivates sensitivity
